ground_truth: Lt. Dan pushes Forrest away, and Forrest steps back as Lt. Dan flips back over, then pulls himself back up onto his wheelchair and breathes heavily. An anchorman reports in front of the White House. Forrest looks at the fat man on the bus bench. President Nixon holds the plaque, and Forrest speaks on the phone, then hangs up. President Nixon makes a resignation speech on TV, and the television cuts to a shot of President Nixon standing outside Air Force One with his hands in the peace sign. An officer hands Forrest an envelope and then walks away. Forrest takes his paddle and runs out of the gymnasium. Mrs. Gump walks out of the house and smiles as Forrest walks up to the house, wearing his uniform. Mrs. Gump and Forrest walk into the house, where there are stacks of ping-pong paddles and life-sized cardboard cutouts of Forrest playing ping-pong. Forrest walks up to a shack on the edge of the Bayou as a group of black kids play in the front yard. Bubba's mother, Mrs. Blue, and her other children look at Forrest as he steps over to Bubba's tombstone and pulls out notes from his pocket, then walks along a wooden pier. Forrest pays an old black shrimper a large wad of cash and stands at the grave before steering his shrimping boat. The boat is old and rusty as Forrest unleashes his nets, and his catch of the day drops to the deck, which consists of a bunch of garbage and shells. Forrest picks up one shrimp and pulls a couple of shrimp out of a bucket. The old shrimper begins to walk away, then stops and looks at Forrest as he paints a name on the side of his boat. Disco lights flash, and people dance while a guy asks a girl to dance. Forrest stands at the helm as the boat glides across the water. Drug paraphernalia and a large wad of cash are spread out on a table as a man drops a syringe on the table and reaches over to touch Jenny, who is pale with dark lines under her eyes. Jenny smears some lines of cocaine on a mirror and looks at herself in the mirror, then steps out onto the high-rise balcony and steps up on a table to stand on the edge of the balcony. A busy street lies many stories below as Jenny looks down to the intersection, then slips over the edge. She regains her balance, turns and looks back at the intersection below, and begins to get down from the edge. Jenny grabs a hold of the ledge and carefully climbs down, then sits down on a chair and rocks back and forth as she cries.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: Forrest is pushed away by Lt. Dan, and a step back is taken by Forrest as Lt. Dan is flipped back over, then he is pulled back up onto his wheelchair by himself, and heavy breathing is done by him. In front of the White House, an anchorman reports. The fat man on the bus bench is looked at by Forrest. The plaque is held by President Nixon, and Forrest is spoken to on the phone by him, then he hangs it up. A resignation speech is made by President Nixon on TV, and a shot of President Nixon standing outside Air Force One with his hands in the peace sign is shown by the television. Forrest is handed an envelope by an officer, and then he walks away. His paddle is taken by Forrest, and out of the gymnasium, he runs. The house is walked out of by Mrs. Gump, and she smiles as the house is approached by Forrest, wearing his uniform. Mrs. Gump and Forrest enter the house, where stacks of ping-pong paddles and life-sized cardboard cutouts of Forrest playing ping-pong are found. A shack on the edge of the Bayou is approached by Forrest as a group of black kids play in the front yard. Bubba's tombstone is stepped over to by Forrest, where Bubba's mother, Mrs. Blue, and her other children look at him as notes are pulled out from his pocket by him, then along a wooden pier, he walks. A large wad of cash is paid by Forrest to an old black shrimper, and at the grave, he stands before the shrimping boat is steered by him. The nets are unleashed by Forrest as the old and rusty boat is maneuvered, and a catch of the day, consisting of a bunch of garbage and shells, drops to the deck. One shrimp is picked up by Forrest, and a couple of shrimp are pulled out of a bucket by him. The old shrimper walks away, then stops and looks at Forrest as a name is painted on the side of his boat by him. Disco lights flash, and dancing is done by people while a girl is asked to dance by a guy. At the helm, stands Forrest as the boat is glided across the water by him. A syringe is dropped on the table by a man, and Jenny, who is pale with dark lines under her eyes, is reached over to touch. Some lines of cocaine are smeared on a mirror by Jenny, and at herself in the mirror, she looks, then she steps out onto the high-rise balcony and a step up on a table is taken by her to stand on the edge of the balcony. Many stories below lies a busy street as the intersection is looked down at by Jenny, then she slips over the edge. Her balance is regained by her, and the intersection below is turned and looked back at by her, and she begins to get down from the edge. The ledge is grabbed by Jenny, and carefully she climbs down, then a chair is sat on by her, and she rocks back and forth as crying is done by her.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: Lt. Dan pushes Forrest, who steps back as Lt. Dan flips over, pulls himself onto his wheelchair, and breathes heavily. An anchorman reports at the White House. Forrest looks at a fat man on the bus bench. President Nixon holds a plaque, Forrest speaks on the phone, then hangs up. Nixon resigns on TV, then stands outside Air Force One with peace signs. An officer gives Forrest an envelope and leaves. Forrest grabs his paddle and runs from the gym. Mrs. Gump smiles as Forrest, in uniform, approaches the house. They enter, surrounded by ping-pong paddles and cutouts of Forrest playing. Forrest visits a Bayou shack where black kids play. Bubba's mother and siblings watch as Forrest visits Bubba's tombstone, pulls notes from his pocket, and walks along a pier. Forrest pays an old shrimper a large wad of cash, stands at the grave, then steers his rusty shrimping boat. He unleashes nets, catching garbage and shells, picks up shrimp, and paints a name on his boat. Disco lights flash as people dance. Forrest stands at the helm as the boat glides. Drug paraphernalia and cash are on a table as a man drops a syringe and touches Jenny, who is pale. Jenny smears cocaine on a mirror, looks at herself, steps onto a high-rise balcony, and stands on the edge. She looks down, slips, regains balance, and climbs down, then sits and cries.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description:
Lt. Dan, with a sudden and forceful motion, pushes Forrest away, causing Forrest to take a step back. Lt. Dan then flips back over with determination and pulls himself back up onto his wheelchair, breathing heavily from the exertion. Meanwhile, an anchorman is seen reporting live in front of the iconic White House. Forrest, sitting on a bus bench, glances over at the overweight man seated nearby. In another scene, President Nixon is shown holding a plaque, and Forrest is seen speaking on the phone before he hangs up. The television then broadcasts President Nixon delivering his resignation speech, and the screen transitions to a shot of President Nixon standing outside Air Force One, his hands raised in the familiar peace sign gesture. An officer approaches Forrest, handing him an envelope before walking away. Forrest, with a sense of urgency, grabs his paddle and dashes out of the gymnasium. 

Mrs. Gump emerges from the house, a warm smile on her face, as she sees Forrest approaching the house, proudly wearing his uniform. Together, Mrs. Gump and Forrest enter the house, where they are greeted by stacks of ping-pong paddles and life-sized cardboard cutouts of Forrest in action, playing ping-pong. Forrest then makes his way to a small shack situated on the edge of the Bayou, where a group of black children are joyfully playing in the front yard. Bubba's mother, Mrs. Blue, along with her other children, watches Forrest as he steps over to Bubba's tombstone. He pulls out some notes from his pocket, then proceeds to walk along a wooden pier. At the pier, Forrest pays an elderly black shrimper a substantial wad of cash and stands solemnly at the grave before taking the helm of his shrimping boat. The boat, old and rusty, creaks as Forrest releases his nets, and the day's catch, consisting mostly of garbage and shells, drops onto the deck. Forrest picks up a single shrimp and pulls a couple more shrimp out of a bucket. The old shrimper begins to walk away but pauses, turning to look at Forrest as he carefully paints a name on the side of his boat.

In a different scene, disco lights flash vibrantly, and people are seen dancing energetically while a guy asks a girl to join him on the dance floor. Forrest stands confidently at the helm as his boat glides smoothly across the water. Inside a dimly lit room, drug paraphernalia and a large wad of cash are spread out on a table. A man drops a syringe onto the table and reaches over to touch Jenny, who appears pale and weary, with dark lines under her eyes. Jenny, in a moment of reflection, smears some lines of cocaine on a mirror and gazes at her own reflection. She then steps out onto the high-rise balcony, climbing up onto a table to stand precariously on the edge. Below, a busy street lies many stories down, and Jenny looks down at the intersection, feeling the pull of the void. She slips over the edge but manages to regain her balance, turning to look back at the bustling intersection below. With a sense of relief, she begins to carefully climb down from the edge, grabbing hold of the ledge for support. Once safely down, Jenny sits on a chair, rocking back and forth as tears stream down her face.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description:
Lt. Dan, in a moment marked by abruptness and intensity, forcefully shoves Forrest away, causing Forrest to take an involuntary step backward due to the impact. With determination etched on his face, Lt. Dan then flips himself back over with great resolve and exerts all his strength to pull himself back up onto his wheelchair, his breathing coming in heavy gasps from the effort he expended. Meanwhile, elsewhere, an anchorman is observed delivering a live report in front of the iconic and historically significant White House. Forrest, who is seated on a bus bench, casually glances over at the overweight man sitting in close proximity to him. In a different scene, President Nixon is depicted holding a plaque, and Forrest is seen engaging in a conversation on the phone before he hangs it up. The television screen then displays President Nixon as he gives his resignation speech, and seamlessly shifts to a shot of President Nixon standing outside the majestic Air Force One, his hands raised high in the well-known peace sign gesture. An officer approaches Forrest with purpose, handing him an envelope before turning away and walking off. Sensing urgency, Forrest quickly grabs his paddle and dashes out of the echoing gymnasium with speed.

Mrs. Gump, emerging gracefully from the house, wears a warm and welcoming smile on her face as she spots Forrest approaching the house, adorning his uniform with pride. Together, Mrs. Gump and Forrest step into the house, where they are greeted by towering stacks of ping-pong paddles and life-sized cardboard cutouts capturing Forrest in the action of playing ping-pong. Forrest then finds his way to a small shack located on the edge of the Bayou, where a lively group of black children are joyfully playing in the front yard. Bubba's mother, Mrs. Blue, along with her other children, observes Forrest as he makes his way over to Bubba's tombstone. He pulls out some notes from his pocket and then continues to walk along a wooden pier. At the pier's end, Forrest hands an elderly black shrimper a substantial wad of cash and stands solemnly at the grave before taking the helm of his shrimping boat. The boat, old and rusted from years of use, creaks audibly as Forrest releases his nets, and the day’s catch, made up mostly of garbage and shells, drops onto the deck. Forrest picks up a single shrimp and then pulls a couple more shrimp from a bucket. The old shrimper, beginning to walk away, pauses briefly, turning back to look at Forrest as he carefully paints a name on the side of his boat.

In a contrasting scene, disco lights flash vibrantly, casting colorful patterns, and people are seen dancing with energetic enthusiasm while a guy confidently asks a girl to accompany him onto the dance floor. Forrest stands with assuredness at the helm as his boat glides smoothly across the serene surface of the water. Inside a dimly lit room, drug paraphernalia and a large wad of cash are spread out haphazardly on a table. A man carelessly drops a syringe onto the table and reaches over to touch Jenny, who appears pale and weary, with dark lines prominently visible under her eyes. Jenny, caught in a moment of reflection, smears some lines of cocaine on a mirror and gazes deeply at her own reflection. She then steps out onto the high-rise balcony, climbing up onto a table to stand precariously on the edge of danger. Below her, a busy street teems with activity many stories down, and Jenny looks down at the intersection, feeling the pull of the void below. She slips over the edge but manages to regain her fragile balance, turning to look back at the bustling intersection below her. With a sense of immense relief, she begins to carefully climb down from the edge, grabbing hold of the ledge for support. Once safely down, Jenny sinks into a chair, rocking back and forth as tears flow freely down her face.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: Lt. Dan, with a sudden burst of energy, pushes Forrest away, causing Forrest to instinctively step back, creating a small distance between them. As Lt. Dan flips back over, he uses his arms to pull himself back up onto his wheelchair, his chest rising and falling as he breathes heavily, trying to regain his composure. Meanwhile, an anchorman stands in front of the White House, delivering a report with a serious expression. Forrest, sitting on a bus bench, turns his attention to a fat man seated nearby, observing him with curiosity. In another scene, President Nixon holds a plaque with a sense of pride, while Forrest, in a different location, picks up a phone, speaks into it briefly, and then gently places the receiver back down, ending the call. The television screen then transitions to President Nixon making a resignation speech, his voice resonating through the room, before cutting to a shot of him standing outside Air Force One, his hands raised in the iconic peace sign gesture. An officer approaches Forrest, handing him an envelope with a formal demeanor, and then turns to walk away, leaving Forrest to contemplate the contents. Forrest, filled with determination, grabs his paddle and swiftly exits the gymnasium, his footsteps echoing in the empty space. As Mrs. Gump emerges from the house, a warm smile spreads across her face, welcoming Forrest as he approaches, dressed smartly in his uniform. Together, Mrs. Gump and Forrest enter the house, where they are greeted by stacks of ping-pong paddles and life-sized cardboard cutouts of Forrest in action, playing ping-pong. Forrest then makes his way to a shack on the edge of the Bayou, where a group of black kids play joyfully in the front yard. Bubba's mother, Mrs. Blue, along with her other children, watches Forrest with a mix of curiosity and recognition as he steps over to Bubba's tombstone, pulling out notes from his pocket, reflecting on memories, before walking along a wooden pier. At the pier, Forrest hands an old black shrimper a large wad of cash, a gesture of gratitude and respect, before standing solemnly at the grave. He then takes control of his shrimping boat, an old and rusty vessel, and releases the nets into the water. As the nets are pulled back up, the catch of the day spills onto the deck, revealing a disappointing haul of garbage and shells. Undeterred, Forrest picks up one shrimp, examining it closely, and then pulls a couple more shrimp out of a bucket, assessing his modest success. The old shrimper begins to walk away, but pauses, turning back to watch Forrest as he carefully paints a name on the side of his boat, marking it with a sense of ownership and hope. In a different scene, disco lights flash energetically, casting colorful patterns across the room as people dance with abandon. A guy, caught up in the moment, asks a girl to dance, his voice barely audible over the music. Meanwhile, Forrest stands confidently at the helm of his boat, guiding it smoothly across the water. In a stark contrast, a table is cluttered with drug paraphernalia and a large wad of cash, a man carelessly dropping a syringe onto the table before reaching over to touch Jenny, who appears pale and weary, dark lines etched under her eyes. Jenny, in a moment of desperation, smears lines of cocaine on a mirror, her reflection staring back at her, before she steps out onto the high-rise balcony. She climbs onto a table, standing precariously on the edge of the balcony, her eyes drawn to the busy street many stories below. As she looks down at the intersection, a moment of fear grips her, causing her to slip slightly over the edge. Regaining her balance, she turns away from the dizzying height, her gaze lingering on the intersection below, before she carefully begins to climb down from the edge. With a firm grip on the ledge, she lowers herself safely, then collapses into a chair, her body rocking back and forth as she cries, overwhelmed by the emotions of the moment.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: Lt. Dan pushes Forrest away, flips back over, and pulls himself onto his wheelchair, breathing heavily. An anchorman reports in front of the White House as Forrest observes a man on the bus bench. President Nixon holds a plaque, and Forrest makes a phone call before hanging up. Nixon's resignation speech plays on TV, followed by a shot of him outside Air Force One with a peace sign. An officer hands Forrest an envelope and departs. Forrest grabs his paddle and exits the gymnasium. Mrs. Gump smiles as she and Forrest, in uniform, enter the house filled with ping-pong paddles and cutouts of Forrest playing. Forrest approaches a shack by the Bayou, where children play, and Mrs. Blue and her family watch him visit Bubba's tombstone. He reads notes, walks along a pier, pays a shrimper, and stands at the grave before steering his old, rusty shrimping boat. He releases the nets, and the catch, mostly garbage and shells, drops to the deck. Forrest picks up a shrimp and a few more from a bucket. The shrimper pauses, watching Forrest paint a name on the boat. Disco lights flash as people dance, and a guy invites a girl to dance. Forrest stands at the helm as the boat glides across the water. Inside, drug paraphernalia and cash cover a table as a man drops a syringe and reaches for Jenny, who is pale and tired. Jenny smears cocaine on a mirror, looks at herself, then steps onto a high-rise balcony, standing on the edge. She looks down at the busy street below, slips, regains her balance, and steps back from the edge. Jenny carefully climbs down, sits in a chair, and rocks back and forth, crying.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: Lt. Dan, a Vietnam War veteran who lost both his legs and struggles with his new reality, pushes Forrest away, and Forrest steps back as Lt. Dan flips back over, then pulls himself back up onto his wheelchair, breathing heavily as he copes with the physical strain. An anchorman reports in front of the White House, a historic building and the residence of the U.S. President. Forrest looks at the fat man on the bus bench, a scene reminiscent of his many encounters with strangers while waiting for the bus. President Nixon, who was embroiled in the Watergate scandal leading to his resignation, holds the plaque, and Forrest speaks on the phone, then hangs up. President Nixon makes a resignation speech on TV, and the television cuts to a shot of President Nixon standing outside Air Force One, the official aircraft of the President, with his hands in the peace sign, a gesture he often used. An officer hands Forrest an envelope, a common military communication method, and then walks away. Forrest takes his paddle and runs out of the gymnasium, reminiscent of his time as a ping-pong champion, a sport he mastered which gained him international attention. Mrs. Gump, Forrest's devoted mother who always supported him, walks out of the house and smiles as Forrest walks up to the house, wearing his military uniform. Mrs. Gump and Forrest walk into the house, where there are stacks of ping-pong paddles and life-sized cardboard cutouts of Forrest playing ping-pong, evidence of his fame from winning championships. Forrest walks up to a shack on the edge of the Bayou, an area in Louisiana known for its unique ecosystem, as a group of black kids play in the front yard. Bubba's mother, Mrs. Blue, part of a community dependent on shrimping, and her other children look at Forrest as he steps over to Bubba's tombstone, remembering his late friend, and pulls out notes from his pocket, then walks along a wooden pier. Forrest pays an old black shrimper a large wad of cash, likely to buy a shrimping boat, and stands at the grave before steering his shrimping boat, named after his friend. The boat is old and rusty, a reflection of Forrest's modest beginnings in the shrimping business, as Forrest unleashes his nets, and his catch of the day drops to the deck, which consists of a bunch of garbage and shells. Forrest picks up one shrimp and pulls a couple of shrimp out of a bucket, hopeful for a successful catch. The old shrimper begins to walk away, then stops and looks at Forrest as he paints a name on the side of his boat, paying tribute to his friend by naming it Jenny after the woman he loves. Disco lights flash, and people dance at a nightclub, a popular scene during the 1970s, while a guy asks a girl to dance. Forrest stands at the helm as the boat glides across the water, reflecting his newfound skill as a captain. Drug paraphernalia and a large wad of cash are spread out on a table, indicating a scene of illegal activity, as a man drops a syringe on the table and reaches over to touch Jenny, who is pale with dark lines under her eyes, showing the toll of her lifestyle choices. Jenny smears some lines of cocaine on a mirror, a habit she's fallen into, and looks at herself in the mirror, then steps out onto the high-rise balcony of her apartment, a place of solitude in her chaotic life, and steps up on a table to stand on the edge of the balcony. A busy street lies many stories below as Jenny looks down to the intersection, a moment of contemplation amidst her turmoil, then slips over the edge. She regains her balance, turns and looks back at the intersection below, and begins to get down from the edge, an act of self-preservation. Jenny grabs a hold of the ledge and carefully climbs down, then sits down on a chair and rocks back and forth as she cries, overwhelmed by her situation.

In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. Disco lights flash and people dance while a guy asks a girl to dance. Forrest stands at the helm as the boat glides across the water. Drug paraphernalia and a large wad of cash are spread out on a table as a man drops a syringe on the table and reaches over to touch Jenny who is pale with dark lines under her eyes. Jenny smears some lines of cocaine on a mirror and looks at herself in the mirror then steps out onto the highrise balcony and steps up on a table to stand on the edge of the balcony. A busy street lies many stories below as Jenny looks down to the intersection then slips over the edge. She regains her balance turns and looks back at the intersection below and begins to get down from the edge. Jenny grabs a hold of the ledge and carefully climbs down then sits down on a chair and rocks back and forth as she cries.

On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. During a clandestine meeting in a snowcovered mountain lodge two rival spies exchange cryptic messages hinting at an imminent global conspiracy. their whispered words carried off by the howling wind. Inside a lavish 1920s speakeasy a troubled jazz musician pours his soul into a melancholic melody every note echoing the bittersweet memories of lost love and shattered dreams. Bubba's mother Mrs Blue and her other children look at Forrest as he steps over to Bubba's tombstone and pulls out notes from his pocket then walks along a wooden pier. Forrest pays an old black shrimper a large wad of cash and stands at the grave before steering his shrimping boat. The boat is old and rusty as Forrest unleashes his nets and his catch of the day drops to the deck which consists of a bunch of garbage and shells. Forrest picks up one shrimp and pulls a couple of shrimp out of a bucket. The old shrimper begins to walk away then stops and looks at Forrest as he paints a name on the side of his boat. Disco lights flash and people dance while a guy asks a girl to dance. Forrest stands at the helm as the boat glides across the water. Drug paraphernalia and a large wad of cash are spread out on a table as a man drops a syringe on the table and reaches over to touch Jenny who is pale with dark lines under her eyes. Jenny smears some lines of cocaine on a mirror and looks at herself in the mirror then steps out onto the highrise balcony and steps up on a table to stand on the edge of the balcony. A busy street lies many stories below as Jenny looks down to the intersection then slips over the edge. She regains her balance turns and looks back at the intersection below and begins to get down from the edge. Jenny grabs a hold of the ledge and carefully climbs down then sits down on a chair and rocks back and forth as she cries.

test_cases.name: Deletion (~50%)
test_cases.description: Lt Dan pushes Forrest away and Forrest steps back as Lt Dan flips back over then pulls himself back up onto his wheelchair and breathes heavily. An anchorman reports in front of the White House. Forrest looks at the fat man on the bus bench. President Nixon holds the plaque and Forrest speaks on the phone then hangs up. President Nixon makes a resignation speech on TV and the television cuts to a shot of President Nixon standing outside. Air Force One with his hands in the peace sign. Forrest stands at the helm as the boat glides across the water. Drug paraphernalia and a large wad of cash are spread out on a table as a man drops a syringe on the table and reaches over to touch Jenny who is pale with dark lines under her eyes. Jenny smears some lines of cocaine on a mirror and looks at herself in the mirror then steps out onto the highrise balcony and steps up on a table to stand on the edge of the balcony. A busy street lies many stories below as Jenny looks down to the intersection then slips over the edge. She regains her balance turns and looks back at the intersection below and begins to get down from the edge. Jenny grabs a hold of the ledge and carefully climbs down then sits down on a chair and rocks back and forth as she cries.

test_cases.name: Deletion (~80%)
test_cases.description: Lt Dan pushes Forrest away and Forrest steps back as Lt Dan flips back over then pulls himself back up onto his wheelchair and breathes heavily. An anchorman reports in front of the White House. A busy street lies many stories below as Jenny looks down to the intersection then slips over the edge. She regains her balance turns and looks back at the intersection below and begins to get down from the edge. Jenny grabs a hold of the ledge and carefully climbs down then sits down on a chair and rocks back and forth as she cries.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Captain Bob nudges Hank aside, and Hank retreats as Captain Bob spins forward, then hoists himself back onto his tricycle and sighs deeply. A weatherman narrates beside the Capitol Building. Hank gazes at the thin lady on the train stop. Prime Minister Wilson clutches the trophy, and Hank listens on the radio, then disconnects. Prime Minister Wilson delivers a farewell address on the radio, and the broadcast switches to a view of Prime Minister Wilson beside a chopper with his hands in the victory salute. A firefighter hands Hank a flyer and then jogs away. Hank grabs his bat and bolts out of the auditorium. Aunt May exits the apartment and grins as Hank approaches the building, sporting his costume. Aunt May and Hank enter the apartment, where there are piles of tennis rackets and life-sized foam statues of Hank playing tennis. Hank approaches a cabin on the edge of the swamp as a bunch of young girls skip in the backyard. Tim's aunt, Mrs. Green, and her other kin gaze at Hank as he strolls over to Tim's marker and retrieves papers from his backpack, then wanders along a stone path. Hank gives an elderly white hunter a hefty stack of bills and stands by the marker before guiding his fishing vessel. The vessel is ancient and creaky as Hank casts his lines, and his haul of the day tumbles onto the floor, comprising mostly rubbish and pebbles. Hank picks up one fish and extracts a pair from a crate. The elderly hunter begins to stroll away, then halts and glances at Hank as he writes a title on the hull of his vessel. Strobe lights dazzle, and folks sway while a boy invites a woman to dance. Hank stands at the wheel as the vessel drifts across the sea. Party favors and a hefty stack of bills are scattered on a counter as a woman drops a spoon on the surface and reaches over to touch Annie, who is tired with deep creases around her eyes. Annie spreads some lines of flour on a window and observes herself in the glass, then steps onto the rooftop terrace and climbs up on a stool to stand on the brink of the terrace. A bustling avenue sprawls many flights below as Annie glances down to the crosswalk, then stumbles over the brink. She recovers her footing, turns and peers back at the crosswalk below, and starts to descend from the brink. Annie clutches the sill and cautiously scales down, then sits on a stool and rocks gently as she sobs.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Lt. Dan pushes Forrest away, who then steps back as Lt. Dan adjusts himself on his wheelchair. The scene shifts to an anchorman reporting at the White House, where President Nixon eventually makes a resignation speech. Forrest is handed an envelope by an officer and later runs out of a gymnasium. Mrs. Gump greets Forrest at home, and inside, they find stacks of ping-pong paddles with cutouts of Forrest playing. Forrest visits Bubba's grave, walking past Mrs. Blue and her children, then pays an old shrimper before taking a rusty shrimping boat out. His catch is mostly garbage, but he finds a couple of shrimp. Meanwhile, Jenny is involved with drugs, visibly distressed, and nearly falls from a high-rise balcony but regains composure. She climbs down safely and sits, crying.
